resources.string: Search building name or code, e.g., PCL, UTC
Electrical Engineering Class of 2015\nComputer Science Class of 2015
Love the app? Hate it? Suggestions? Snide remarks?

Check this if Blackboard crashes on launch, might fix it.
Help me help you! No personal information will be sent.
Send anonymous information about my courses to help improve UTilities.
Also, a huge thanks to fellow UT student, Kevin Lin, for providing many of the graphical assets for this application. It would be an ugly jumble of gray buttons if not for him.

This Privacy Policy has been created to answer a few of the questions that have come up about how UTilities handles its users' data, specifically the users' UT EID and password.
---
 Q: What happens when I tick the "Persistent login" preference and enter my UT credentials into UTilities?

 A: UTilities saves your EID in its settings file, and it encrypts and then saves your password in its settings file.
---
 Q: My password is encrypted? Does that mean it is super-ultra-mega-secure?

 A: Unfortunately not, while the encryption is an added layer of protection on top of Android's own built-in security, if someone were to steal your device and have the Android know-how, they would be able to extract your password from UTilities' settings. This means if you lose your device, change your UT password! (as you should do with all of your important accounts if you lose your smartphone).
---
 Q: What does UTilities do with my UT credentials anyway?

 A: UTilities sends your credentials to UT's servers when it needs to log in, and that is the only place it sends them. Your UT EID and password will never be shared with anyone except The University of Texas at Austin.
